ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SAFETY MEASURES AT CONSTRUCTION WORKSITES
(Surprise raids)


    1. Mr Lim Boon Heng: To ask the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour why it is necessary to conduct surprise raids at construction worksites in order to enforce safety legislation and whether such raids have resulted in a significant improvement of safety measures at construction worksites.

Column: 1232



     Mr Speaker: Mr Lim Boon Heng.

     Encik Saidi Haji Shariff (Kaki Bukit): Question No 1, Sir.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, surprise inspections are conducted on contractors who have unsatisfactory safety records or have shown an indifferent attitude towards safety at worksites. This is necessary to impress upon such contractors the need to rectify unsafe conditions before workers are hurt or killed. Many of the worksites

Column: 1233

raided were found to have unsafe conditions. Hence, surprise raids on these contractors are necessary and will be continued.

    There is improvement of safety measures at construction worksites as a result of such raids. Contractors are taking steps to improve safety provisions so that they will not be the targets of future raids. Safety personnel at the worksites have also indicated that contractors are more receptive to their proposals and suggestions to improve safety measures.

     Mr Liew Kok Pun (Boon Teck): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister of State for Labour what measures will be taken to reduce accidents in the construction industry?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry will take the following measures to reduce accidents in the construction industry.

    (a) Amending the Building Operations and Works of Engineering Construction Regulations to make further requirements on the provision of safe working platforms, safe access to workplaces and proper overhead shelters. These amendments will indirectly encourage and promote the use of metal scaffoldings. The use of metal scaffoldings will also have the effect of changing the method of construction. Construction will be carried out inwards from properly erected scaffoldings and working platforms. This will help to prevent many of the accidents resulting from workers falling from heights and workers being struck by falling objects.

    (b) The Ministry will also continue with its programme of stringent enforcement at construction worksites. It will also continue to conduct surprise inspections and swoops on worksite recalcitrant contractors.

    (c) Finally, the Ministry will continue with its programme of safety mass orientation for workers in the construction industry. This mass orientation will acquaint existing and new workers with the hazards of the industry and the remedial measures.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister of State say

Column: 1234

whether any contractors have been prosecuted as a result of the surprise checks and, if so, how many?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, since the raids were started last year, a total of 76 worksites have been raided. In 1980, four stop-work orders were issued, 68 offences were compounded and a total of $8,525 were collected as fines. In 1981, a total of 12 stop-work orders were issued, 50 offences were compounded and a total of $10,300 in fines were collected.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: None was prosecuted?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: None. Mr Ho See Beng;

EMPLOYMENT ACT
(Protection against dismissals)


    2. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (a) whether he is satisfied that the present Employment Act gives sufficient protection to a worker with respect to his tenure of appointment; (b) whether he is aware that there are certain sections of the Act that leave workers completely at the mercy of the employer; and (c) whether he thinks it is necessary to have a law against unfair dismissal.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Employment Act provides adequate protection for employees against unfair termination or dismissal. Employees who feel that they have been terminated or dismissed without just cause or excuse can appeal to the Minister for redress. If the Minister is satisfied that the dismissal has been made without just cause or excuse, the employer will be ordered either to reinstate the employee or to pay compensation. The maximum penalty on the employer for not heeding the Minister's order for reinstatement or compensation is a $5,000 fine or imprisonment up to 12 months, or both.

    The rights and obligations of employees and employers are clearly spelt out in the Act. Since its promulgation, the Act has been operating smoothly in safeguarding the interest and welfare of employees.

    Over the past five years a total of 141 appeals against dismissal were received. In 87 of these cases, our investigations

Column: 1235

confirmed that the dismissals were justified.

    In 10 cases, however, the Ministry ruled that the dismissals were wrongful.In some of these instances, the dismissals were carried out without a proper inquiry or without grounds to substantiate the charge. Reinstatement of the dismissed workers was ordered by the Minister in five cases and compensation was paid out in the other five cases. The remaining 44 cases were amicably settled through conciliation at the Ministry. In the majority of these cases, during conciliation the dismissed workers accepted the dismissal and the employers also agreed to grant compensation as both parties were found to be partially wrong in their actions. From these figures, it is clear that employers generally have not abused their rights in terminating or dismissing employees. It is, therefore, unnecessary to modify the current law governing dismissal.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. The appeal to the Minister only lies in the case of a dismissal of a worker for misconduct. Is there any protection for the worker who has put in, say, 15 or 20 years of service and he is then suddenly told, "Your services are no longer required. Here are four weeks' wages. Goodbye."?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are some employers who, instead of conducting an inquiry into the employees' misconduct and to avoid appeals against dismissal, as mentioned by the Member for Anson, choose the easy way out by terminating the services of such employees in accordance with section 10 of the Act, that is, giving them the appropriate notice to terminate their services. There are other employers who also terminate the services of their employees without valid reasons or to save costs. The affected employees have no recourse to appeal for reinstatement on the grounds of unfair termination, as the termination is in accordance with the law.

    However, although the Employment Act does not empower the Minister to inquire into termination cases, my Ministry has

Column: 1236

investigated cases of unjust termination which are brought to our attention. That has been done in the past. The figure of 141 appeals, which I quoted earlier on, includes such cases.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, is the Minister aware that the Act provides that before a worker can be dismissed for misconduct, there should be an inquiry? Is the Minister aware that by a decision of the Court of Appeal in Singapore it has been held that there need be no inquiry held before a worker is dismissed? Will the Minister consider taking steps to amend the legislation to put that right?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not see the point raised by the Member for Anson about the Court of Appeal. We are talking about the Employment Act. The Employment Act provides that there must be just cause for dismissal of employees by the employers and there must be proper inquiry conducted by the employers. If not, there is always recourse for the employees to refer the matter to the Ministry of Labour and the Labour officers will then carry out an investigation.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, my supplementary question is this. In my experience as a trade unionist, I have come across many cases of dismissal, and when these cases are referred to the Ministry of Labour for conciliation, the Ministry has been able to conciliate these cases very amicably. Can the Minister confirm whether there has been any case handled by the conciliation officers which has proved to be unjust to the workers?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is no. When a matter is referred to the Ministry of Labour, it will be handled by a senior Labour officer. A thorough investigation will be carried out and a report or recommendation will be submitted to the Minister, through the Director of Labour Relations, then to the Deputy Secretary and then to the Permanent Secretary. So the inquiry is made at various levels of the investigation in the Ministry to ensure that the appeals are thoroughly looked into.

Column: 1237



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps I did not make myself clear to the Minister. The point I am making is this. The Act at the moment requires an employer to hold an inquiry before he dismisses him for misconduct. There is a decision of a Court of Appeal which says that that is not necessary, that an employer can dismiss a man without an inquiry, and the remedy merely is, for the man to take the employer to court in an action for wrongful dismissal and recover four weeks' wages.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the point raised by the Member for Anson is irrelevant. That is a Court of Appeal. We are talking about the Ministry of Labour. I am not going to make a judgment on the wisdom of the Appeal Judges. The choice rests with the employee, whether he wants to refer the case to the Court under the common law or refer it to the Ministry of Labour for an appeal. We are talking about the Labour Ministry.

INDUSTRIAL ACCIDENTS


    3. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (a) how many accidents have occurred in the various industries in Singapore over the past five years; (b) what measures the Ministry of Labour has taken to reduce these accidents; and (c) whether he is satisfied that the Ministry is doing enough to ensure that the lives of workers are not unnecessarily put in danger.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, there were a total of 4,575 accidents reported to the Factory Inspectorate in 1977 as compared with 4,554 in 1978, 5,277 in 1979, 6,087 in 1980 and 6,046 in 1981. Although the number of accidents has increased over the years, the industrial safety situation has not deteriorated. The increasing number of accidents has to be interpreted in the light of the increasing number of workers employed in industry and the resultant increased exposure to risk in terms of man-hours worked. To give proper weight to these factors, the accident severity and frequency rates have to be calculated to establish if the industrial accident situation

Column: 1238

has improved or deteriorated. The accident severity rates in 1977 was 501 mandays lost per million man-hours worked compared with 504 man-days lost per million man-hours worked in 1981. The accident frequency rates for the five years from 1977 to 1981 were kept within the limits of 5.0 and 6.5 accidents per million man-hours worked. Hence, in these terms, it can be said that the industrial accident situation has not deteriorated.

    My Ministry has taken various measures to improve the industrial accident situation. These measures are as follows:-

     (a) Safety standards

    One measure is to set safety standards to be observed in the industry. These have been prescribed through legislation. Special safety requirements are also laid down to protect workers who are engaged in work which may expose them to risks. For instance, there are special safety provisions for workers who are exposed to the risks of falling objects or debris from heights, asphyxiation and fire and explosion. These standards and requirements are being reviewed continually to ensure that they are up-to-date and relevant.

     (b) Safety Officers

    Certain classes of factories have also been required to employ safety officers and to establish safety committees. These safety officers help to identify hazardous situations and make recommendations to management to rectify them. They also help to implement safety measures.

     (c) Enforcement

    To ensure that safety standards for the protection of workers are complied with, continuous enforcement action has to be taken. To increase efficiency, selective enforcement in factories and industries which are more hazardous has been practised.

     (d) Advisory Committees

    In addition, the Ministry has set up Advisory Committees to look into the special problems encountered by the ship-building and ship-repairing industry and the construction industry, so that appropriate recommendations on preventive measures can be made.

Column: 1239



     (e) Promotion

    The Ministry places great emphasis on the prevention of accidents and has been continuously promoting safety awareness through the organization of various campaigns, exhibitions, workshops and safety months. Since 1972, a total of 21 of these have been conducted.

     (f) Training and Education

    Furthermore, numerous safety training courses have been conducted for safety personnel, workers, supervisors and management. Special mass orientation and safety instruction courses have also been conducted for workers in the shipbuilding and ship-repairing and the construction industries.

    From the measures just related, it can be seen that the Ministry has spared no efforts to ensure that the lives of our workers are not unnecessarily exposed to risk and jeopardy. In spite of this, the Ministry will continue to look into better ways to prevent accidents at workplaces.

     Mr Liew Kok Pun: Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister of State for Labour whether there is a shortage of registered safety officers and, if so, how serious is the shortage? Also, what steps are being taken by his Ministry to overcome this shortage?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, about 240 safety officers are needed to meet the demand of factories which are required to employ safety officers under the Factories (Safety Officers) Order, 1975, At present, the Ministry has registered about 150 safety officers. The shortage of about 90 registered safety officers is expected to be overcome in the near future when the trainees from the next few batches of the National Productivity Board's safety officers training course successfully complete the course. To ensure an adequate supply of safety officers, the NPB will step up the training of safety officers. The Ministry is also reviewing the three pieces of legislation on safety officers, namely, (1) the Factories (Qualification and Training of Safety Officers) Notification, 1975; (2) the Factories (Registration and Duties of

Column: 1240

Safety Officers) Regulations, 1975; and (3) the Factories (Safety Officers) Order, 1975.

    The needs for the services of safety officers for the various industries, the prerequisite qualification and training and the duties of safety officers to be employed by the various industries will be re-examined in the light of our experience.

OCCUPATIONAL CANCER PREVENTION PROGRAMME
(Progress)


    4. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour what has been the progress of the occupational cancer prevention programme; and whether the Government will consider introducing compulsory medical examination for workers exposed to occupational cancer hazard.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Occupational Cancer Prevention Programme was launched in late 1978 with the following activities:

    (a) Identification of workplaces with occupational cancer hazards;

    (b) Environmental monitoring and control of such workplaces:

    (c) Medical monitoring of workers exposed to cancer hazards;

    (d) Health education of workers and management; and

    (e) Setting up of an informal register of exposed persons.

    In launching this programme, more than 4,800 questionnaires were sent to various establishments to identify users and determine the extent of usage of cancer-causing agents. The Ministry then proceeded to confirm the presence of the hazards and to monitor the workplaces and the workers involved. So far, 63 establishments have been placed under the programme and 910 workers monitored for exposure to two cancer-causing agents, namely, asbestos and benzene. Workers exposed were given talks on how to minimize the risk of exposure and to take precautionary measures. Other cancer-causing agents

Column: 1241

such as arsenic, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, vinyl chloride monomer and aromatic amines, will be included in the programme in phases.

    At present, statutory medical examination is compulsory for workers exposed to asbestos and benzene under the Factories (Asbestos) Regulations, 1980, and the Poisons (Benzene) Rules, 1974, respectively.

MINDEF COMPUTERIZATION PROGRAMME


    5. Mr Sia Khoon Seong asked the Minister of Defence what steps are being taken by his Ministry to encourage greater computerization in line with the stated national policy towards computerization.

     The Minister of State of Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, Mindef is the biggest user of computers in the Republic. Currently, it operates the entire range of computers available: Microcomputers, minicomputers, super minicomputers, mainframe computers, and special purpose computers.

    The Ministry started using computers some 14 years ago. Computers were first used for manpower records, payroll, national service enlistment and control of stores. More complex applications like the computerized allocation of manpower to various vocations according to physique and educational qualifications, and on-line issue of exit permits followed. A study of all possible areas for computerization in Mindef and the SAF was completed last year. Advanced computer techniques are now used to support personnel and logistics management, and for military applications like war games, and studies in mobilization of men and equipment. Much effort is also going into office automation with word processors and small computers.

    Our computer expertise has been put to more than just Defence applications. For example, Members of the House may recall that in the MRT study, a number of officers assisted the Hansen Team in computer simulation to examine the feasibility of an all-bus transport system.

Column: 1242



    Computer professionals in Mindef have been very active in the Government's current computerization effort. They did much of the groundwork leading to the establishment of the National Computer Board and the Institute of Systems Science. In the formulation of the Civil Service Computerization Programme, they made up about half the technical members of the Systems Team which studied the various ministries.

    New approaches in the design of information systems are being introduced. There is an in-house training centre which teaches computer personnel new skills and methods in software development. Much time is spent educating computer users on how to get the most out of their computers. In addition, computer appreciation courses are regularly conducted for those with limited knowledge of what computers can do. The Ministry has also helped organizations like SAFRA and the NTUC set up microcomputer clubs and training centres.

    Because of Singapore's small population, our defence has to be capital-intensive. Mindef will therefore keep abreast of development in computer technology and will continuously exploit opportunities for automation and computerization. We will also contribute, wherever possible, to the national computerization programme.

PHYSICAL FITNESS OF NATIONAL
SERVICEMEN AND RESERVISTS


    6. Mr Sia Khoon Seong asked the Minister of Defence, in view of the important role of physical fitness in our national defence, what steps are being taken to ensure that our National Servicemen and reservists are of adequate physical fitness.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, military training is by its nature physically tough and demanding on active national servicemen and reservists alike. Unless they are physically fit, they will not be able to withstand the rigours of military training and exercises. During the last three years, great emphasis has been given to physical training to stress the importance of physical fitness to all national servicemen. In developing the physical fitness of active

Column: 1243

national servicemen, the SAF hopes to inculcate a permanent physical fitness consciousness and habit which they will follow and maintain in civilian life. Physical fitness tests are conducted at regular intervals to monitor, control and improve the physical fitness standards of our reservists.

    Let me elaborate on the physical fitness programme for full-time national servicemen. During the period of full-time national service, national servicemen are exposed to a wide range of physical fitness programmes which include physical conditioning exercises, long distance runs, combat obstacles course, route marches, swimming, Tae Kwon Do, as well as participation in sports and games which include rugby, football, basketball, etc. The Individual Physical Proficiency Test (IPPT), the Standard Obstacle Course Test, the Swimming Proficiency Test and Tae Kwon Do Grading Test are all conducted at regular intervals to ensure high standards.

    The following test results in 1981 would give some indication of the progress of the SAF physical fitness programme:

     (a) Individual Physical Proficiency Test

    After three months of Basic Military Training (BMT), more than 90% of recruits pass the IPPT which consists of four test exercises: chin-up, push-up, sit-up and a 2.4 km run. All who fail are given additional training and retested until they pass. An illustration of the improvement in physical fitness of our young national servicemen is that although 40% of the recruits cannot perform even three chin-ups at the time of enlistment, most of them are able to satisfy the IPPT's eight chin-ups within 12 months. I can assure Members of this House that a chin-up is indeed difficult.

     (b) Standard Obstacle Course

    Standard Obstacle Course tests are conducted once in Basic Military Training, once in the first year, and once before ROD, at progressively higher test standards. More than 80% pass in each of these three tests. Those who are familiar with the Standard Obstacle Course Test will know that it is indeed a strenuous test

Column: 1244

of stamina, endurance and ruggedness, as it requires a soldier, in full battle order, to run a distance of 1,300 metres and to clear all combat obstacles in 10 minutes.

     (c) Swimming

    Swimming lessons are conducted in BMT for all recruits who cannot swim. All recruits are required to swim a distance of 30 metres using breast stroke and be "drown-proof" for 90 seconds. Generally, all recruits are able to do this by the end of their BMT. During the second year of service, soldiers are upgraded so that they are required to be able to swim 100 metres.

     (d) Tae Kwon Do

    Tae Kwon Do is introduced to combat troops after BMT. A total of five gradings are conducted during the two years of national service. As a result of the training provided during national service, many of our soldiers and reservists take up Tae Kwon Do seriously and continue this martial art in their civilian life.

Reservists

    Let me now elaborate on the physical fitness programme for reservists. After full-time national service, reservists are required to pass the Individual Physical Proficiency Test every six months. In 1981, of the more than 100,000 reservists who took the IPPT, 83% passed at first try, Those who failed were retested, Persistent failures without just cause were given additional training within residence at Pulau Ubin. Despite the short period of in-camp training each year, the SAF makes full use of the programme to emphasize physical fitness wherever possible. Reservists know that they can save themselves a lot of trouble and muscular aches and pains if they keep themselves physically fit the whole year round, instead of exercising only one or two months before each IPPT.

    To further assist reservists to keep fit, the SAF has started the following schemes:

     (a) Keep-fit Apparatus at Community Centres

    From October 1979 to February 1980, the SAF in collaboration with the People's Association installed 22 sets of keep-fit

Column: 1245

apparatus at selected community centres, jogging tracks, SAFRA, and the National Youth Leadership Training Institute. They are specifically located in densely populated areas so that reservists can make full use of them. The keep-fit apparatus consists of the following:

    (1) three sets of Parallel Bars

    (2) one set of Wall/Chin-Up Bars Combination

    (3) one set of Horizontal Ladder.

     (b) Formation of Jogging and Keep-fit Clubs at Community Centres

    Furthermore, the SAF collaborated with the People's Association to form jogging and keep-fit clubs. Reservists staying near each of these community centres are sent letters by the People's Association inviting them to participate. The scheme was launched in April 1980 using reservist Physical Training Instructors to assist.

    The SAF will spare no effort to ensure that through its national servicemen and reservists the keep-fit habit will propagate throughout the entire population. Several part-time familiarization courses on physical fitness have been conducted for members of the People's Association, the National Youth Leadership Training Institute as well as for other youth leaders in community centres. It is hoped that as more and more people respond to these efforts our programme for ensuring that physical fitness will be a life-time commitment by our population will succeed.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister of State whether a survey has been conducted to ascertain the number of reservists making use of such physical fitness apparatus set up in community centres, noting the fact that these community centres are open from about 2.30 p.m. or 3.00 p.m. in the afternoon.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the SAF closely monitors the usage of the keep-fit apparatus. In isolated incidents where the apparatus is not fully utilized, these were removed and placed in other more densely populated centres.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Would the Hon. Minister of State consider removing the physical fitness apparatus now sited at

Column: 1246

Kangkar Community Centre and relocate it at the Punggol Community Centre in Tampines Way?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, keep-fit apparatuses are usually installed after surveys have been made concerning the number of people participating, within any community centre. As a general rule, Members of Parliament are also consulted prior to the installation of such apparatus. I am obviously unable at this particular moment to confirm whether or not the Member for Punggol was consulted in this particular installation.

    If the Member for Punggol would provide me with evidence to suggest that the Kangkar keep-fit apparatus is not being fully utilized, we will only be too glad to take it away. As to whether it would be installed at the new location, we will have to examine that place first, before we decide whether it could not go to some other more worthwhile location.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: I think the Hon. Minister of State was inviting a question from me when I responded to his question that where a physical fitness apparatus is under-utilized - and that is where I meant that the physical fitness apparatus at the Kangkar Community Centre is underutilized - he said that this apparatus should be located at more densely populated areas. The Punggol Community Centre has been built within the Punggol Estate, which has got some 21 blocks comprising 3,091 housing units.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I thank the Member for Punggol for giving me all the detailed statistics. We will look into the numbers and I assure the Member that if the need for the apparatus to be relocated exists we will carry out the relocation.

     Encik Saidi Haji Shariff (Kaki Bukit): Sir, I hope the Hon. Minister of State can do the same thing for Bedok North. We have a physical fitness apparatus which is situated in the sports area, away from the blocks of flats.

    Anyway, my supplementary question is this. May I know whether the Hon. Minister of State is satisfied with the present physical activities programme and facilities provided for our reservists, so that at any one

Column: 1247

time if we round-up from the road 100 national servicemen or reservists, they are physically fit and ready to fight.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, if the apparatus at Bedok North is also under-utilized, which at the moment I am unable to say whether it is or is not, I can assure the Member that it will be looked into. If it is under-utilized, I think there obviously must have been a shift in population in new housing estates.
